text: Step 5 â€” Letâ€™s Put This Bad Boy to Work! ğŸ’ª

The delivery pipeline is up and running, well done! We didnâ€™t build it for the sake of it, though; we want it to get our code deployed. Now weâ€™ll put it to work and start doing some Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery.

When we deployed the pipeline, our application was automatically deployed too. You can see that the pipeline stages are green with green ticks. Indicating that they have run successfully â€” if the pipeline is still running, be patient, it may take 4 or 5 minutes.
You can see our application in the CloudFormation console, called delivery-pipeline-tutorial-application-Dev.
Application Infrastructure

We are using Serverless to help manage and deploy our application. Serverless takes care of lots of the things we need by default. Open up the serverless.yaml file at the root of your repo. It only contains these lines of code:
translation: æˆ‘ä»¬æ­£åœ¨ä½¿ç”¨æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨æ¥å¸®åŠ©ç®¡ç†å’Œéƒ¨ç½²æˆ‘ä»¬çš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚ æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨é»˜è®¤æƒ…å†µä¸‹ä¼šå¤„ç†å¾ˆå¤šæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„ä¸œè¥¿ã€‚ åœ¨ä»“åº“çš„æ ¹ç›®å½•æ‰“å¼€serverless.yamlæ–‡ä»¶ã€‚ å®ƒä»…åŒ…å«ä»¥ä¸‹ä»£ç è¡Œï¼š

text: service: delivery-pipeline-tutorial-applicationprovider:  name: aws  runtime: python3.7package:  exclude:    - tests/**    - delivery/**    - LICENSE    - README.mdfunctions:  helloWorld:    handler: hello_world/hello_world.entry_point    name: HelloWorld    description: A lambda function to help us demonstrate continuous delivery

texts: service: the human-readable name we want our application stack to have (this is the name we see in CloudFormation, with the addition of the environment name suffix).
provider: this tells Serverless that we are deploying to AWS and that by default we want our runtime to be Python 3.7
package: this section explains to Serverless which files and directories are not required for the application to function once it is deployed.

functions: here, we describe which functions (Lambdas) we want to deploy. This includes the entry point (i.e. where the code execution should start from). It also includes some more human-readable information to help us understand what this function does after weâ€™ve deployed it.

text: The serverless.yaml file is another example of IaC. This infrastructure is deployed in the Deploy step of our delivery pipeline.
Application Code
The application code lives in services/hello_world/hello_world.py. It is as simple as its name suggests:
def entry_point(event, context):    #   Lambda Entry Point    return "Hello World"
As soon as it is run it will return the string: Hello World.

You can see this code in AWS Lambda; its name is HelloWorld. You can run the code using the AWS Lambda Test functionality. Open your HelloWorld Lambda function, and at the top of the page, you will see a dropdown menu Select test event. Then choose Configure test events. You can leave the payload as the default and give your test a name; any will do. Click Create.
translation: æ‚¨å¯ä»¥åœ¨AWS Lambdaä¸­çœ‹åˆ°æ­¤ä»£ç ï¼› å®ƒçš„åå­—å«HelloWorldã€‚ æ‚¨å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨AWS Lambda TeståŠŸèƒ½è¿è¡Œä»£ç ã€‚ æ‰“å¼€HelloWorld Lambdaå‡½æ•°ï¼Œåœ¨é¡µé¢é¡¶éƒ¨ï¼Œæ‚¨å°†çœ‹åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªä¸‹æ‹‰èœå•ï¼Œé€‰æ‹©æµ‹è¯•äº‹ä»¶ã€‚ ç„¶åé€‰æ‹©â€œé…ç½®æµ‹è¯•äº‹ä»¶â€ã€‚ æ‚¨å¯ä»¥å°†æœ‰æ•ˆè´Ÿè½½ä¿ç•™ä¸ºé»˜è®¤å€¼ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸ºæµ‹è¯•å‘½åã€‚ ä»»ä½•éƒ½ä¼šåšã€‚ å•å‡»åˆ›å»ºã€‚

text: With your test configured, you can click the Test button. The Lambda will be executed, and a result will appear.
Application Tests
The application has its own unit tests in tests/test_hello_world.py. This test is just checking to see that the returned string is correct, â€œHello Worldâ€:

import unittestfrom services.hello_world import hello_worldclass HelloWorldTest(unittest.TestCase):    def test_greeting(self):        """        Test that I get the correct greeting        """        greeting = hello_world.entry_point("", "")        self.assertEqual(greeting, "Hello World")if __name__ == '__main__':    unittest.main()
This test is run in the Test step of the delivery pipeline.
Making Changes
We are going to make two changes to demonstrate the pipeline in action.

First of all, we will change our application code, the code which runs within our Lambda. Doing this will cause our unit tests to fail. Therefore the pipeline will fail during the Test step. Letâ€™s try it.
Change the services/hello_world/hello_world.py file so that it no longer returns â€œHello Worldâ€:
def entry_point(event, context):    #   Lambda Entry Point    return "Hola Mundo"
Now you need to commit and push the changes:
git add .git commit -m "Changed the returned string"git push origin
translation: git add .git commit -mâ€œæ›´æ”¹è¿”å›çš„å­—ç¬¦ä¸²â€ git push origin

text: Go to your pipeline in AWS CodePipeline. The pipeline has automatically begun processing the latest revision. It will Validate, and this step will pass. It will then attempt the Test step, but this is going to fail.

Notice that the pipeline has stopped at this point. Until the unit tests are fixed, the pipeline is blocked. This is good; it prevents us from deploying broken code. We can confirm the reason for the failure by clicking on the Details link. Follow the execution details; you will see this output:
translation: è¯·æ³¨æ„ï¼Œç®¡é“æ­¤æ—¶å·²åœæ­¢ã€‚ åœ¨ç¡®å®šå•å…ƒæµ‹è¯•ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œç®¡é“å°†è¢«é˜»å¡ã€‚ å¾ˆå¥½ å®ƒé˜»æ­¢æˆ‘ä»¬éƒ¨ç½²æŸåçš„ä»£ç ã€‚ æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡å•å‡»â€œè¯¦ç»†ä¿¡æ¯â€é“¾æ¥æ¥ç¡®è®¤å¤±è´¥çš„åŸå› ã€‚ éµå¾ªæ‰§è¡Œç»†èŠ‚ï¼› æ‚¨å°†çœ‹åˆ°ä»¥ä¸‹è¾“å‡ºï¼š

text: ============================================FAIL: test_greeting (__main__.HelloWorldTest)--------------------------------------------Traceback (most recent call last):File "/codebuild/output/src993431970/src/tests/test_hello_world.py", line 12, in test_greetingself.assertEqual(greeting, "Hello World")AssertionError: 'Hola Mundo' != 'Hello World'--------------------------------------------Ran 1 test in 0.000sFAILED (failures=1)
translation: ============================================å¤±è´¥ï¼štest_greetingï¼ˆ__main__ã€‚ HelloWorldTestï¼‰-------------------------------------------- Tracebackï¼ˆæœ€æ–° æœ€åè°ƒç”¨ï¼‰ï¼šæ–‡ä»¶â€œ /codebuild/output/src993431970/src/tests/test_hello_world.pyâ€ï¼Œç¬¬12è¡Œï¼Œä½äºtest_greetingself.assertEqualï¼ˆgreetingï¼Œâ€œ Hello Worldâ€ï¼‰AssertionErrorï¼š'Hola Mundo'ï¼='Hello World'- -------------------------------------------åœ¨0.000så†…è¿›è¡Œäº†1æ¬¡æµ‹è¯•å¤±è´¥ï¼ˆ å¤±è´¥= 1ï¼‰

text: To get the pipeline moving again, we will need to fix that test. Change the tests/test_hello_world.py file to look like this:

import unittestfrom services.hello_world import hello_worldclass HelloWorldTest(unittest.TestCase):    def test_greeting(self):        """        Test that I get the correct greeting        """        greeting = hello_world.entry_point("", "")        self.assertEqual(greeting, "Hola Mundo")if __name__ == '__main__':    unittest.main()
We will need to commit this change and push it:
git add .git commit -m "Updated failing unit test"git push origin
translation: git add .git commit -mâ€œæ›´æ–°çš„å¤±è´¥çš„å•å…ƒæµ‹è¯•â€ git push origin

text: The pipeline will automatically restart as those changes are picked up.
Our Test step will now pass! Hurray! Not only that, the code will soon make it all the way through to deployment. When it has completed, you can go back to AWS Lambda and retry your configured test:
translation: æˆ‘ä»¬çš„æµ‹è¯•æ­¥éª¤ç°åœ¨å°†é€šè¿‡ï¼ æ¬¢å‘¼ï¼ ä¸ä»…å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œè¯¥ä»£ç è¿˜å°†å¾ˆå¿«è´¯ç©¿æ•´ä¸ªéƒ¨ç½²è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚ å®Œæˆåï¼Œæ‚¨å¯ä»¥è¿”å›AWS Lambdaå¹¶é‡è¯•é…ç½®çš„æµ‹è¯•ï¼š

text: Final Thoughts

Congratulations, youâ€™re now a Continuous Delivery pro! You have configured and built a new CI/CD Pipeline in about 20 minutes, from scratch. Better than that; you now have a baseline for any of your future projects.

You can tweak and modify this baseline as much as you need for each project. Once youâ€™ve done it a couple of times, you will be able to go from an empty repo to a running pipeline in less than 5 minutes! You can reap the benefits of CI/CD no matter how small your project is. You will save that 5 minutes by the time youâ€™ve performed 2 or 3 code commits.
translation: æ‚¨å¯ä»¥æ ¹æ®æ¯ä¸ªé¡¹ç›®çš„éœ€è¦æ¥è°ƒæ•´å’Œä¿®æ”¹æ­¤åŸºå‡†ã€‚ å®Œæˆå‡ æ¬¡åï¼Œæ‚¨å°†å¯ä»¥åœ¨ä¸åˆ°5åˆ†é’Ÿçš„æ—¶é—´å†…ä»ç©ºçš„å­˜å‚¨åº“è½¬åˆ°æ­£åœ¨è¿è¡Œçš„ç®¡é“ï¼ æ— è®ºæ‚¨çš„é¡¹ç›®æœ‰å¤šå°ï¼Œæ‚¨éƒ½å¯ä»¥ä»CI / CDä¸­å—ç›Šã€‚ åœ¨æ‰§è¡Œ2æˆ–3æ¬¡ä»£ç æäº¤ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œæ‚¨å°†èŠ‚çœ5åˆ†é’Ÿã€‚

text: If you have any problems, questions or suggestions about this tutorial, then please let me know in the response section below. Iâ€™d be delighted to help!
Quick Start Guide | AWS CLI
Use this quick start guide to install AWS CLI and create a user profile in minutes.
Step 4 â€” Create the CI/CD Pipeline
With the configuration sorted out, we are ready to create the CI/CD Pipeline. Amazingly, it only takes those few lines of code.

Creating the pipeline is now very simple, look in the delivery/ directory for the bash script create_delivery_pipeline.sh. The file uses the AWS CLI tool if you havenâ€™t already installed this, then follow this 4-minute guide:
Quick Start Guide | AWS CLI
Use this quick start guide to install AWS CLI and create a user profile in minutes.
This script will allow us to create the pipeline with one command. Before we do that, open the file as you may want to tweak it. It executes aws cloudformation create-stack which:
Creates a stack as specified in the template. After the call completes successfully, the stack creation starts.
The command requires a few parameters:

texts: --stack-name This can be anything you wish; it is the name the stack will be known as once it is deployed to AWS.
--template-body This indicates where the file is which contains our configuration, leave this as default.

--profile This tells AWS CLI which profile you wish to use when communicating with AWS. Use the name you created when you set up your profile. If you are using the default profile, you can delete this parameter.
--region This is the region code for which AWS Region you want to put your pipeline in.

--capabilities When using this command to create a stack which contains IAM resources, AWS requires you to state that this is desired, using this parameter explicitly. The value CAPBILITY_IAM tells AWS that we are deliberately creating IAM resources.

text: Run the Command
From a terminal cd to the delivery/ directory. You can now execute the script and create the Pipeline using this command:
./create_delivery_pipeline.sh
After a short pause, you will get a response like this, telling you that the stack creation is underway in AWS:
{    "StackId": "arn:aws:cloudformation:eu-west-1:xxxxxxxxxxxx:stack/delivery-pipeline-tutorial/1234567890-abcde-1234-mnbvc-9876g5543d221"}
Log into the AWS Console and navigate to AWS CloudFormation. You should see your brand new stack, looking something like this:
So far, so good. Your application will be automatically deployed at this point and called delivery-pipeline-tutorial-application-Dev. Weâ€™ll come back to that in a moment.
Now that the pipeline stack has been created we should have a CodePipeline with all the steps we described above. To view the pipeline, choose CodePipeline from the Services menu.
Click on the name of the pipeline to open it.

caption: AWS Console showing the four parts of the pipeline

text: Now we can clearly see the composite parts of the delivery pipeline:

texts: Source: A step which listens to the code repository for any changes.
Validate: AWS CodeBuild step which checks that our codebase is valid.
Test: AWS CodeBuild step which runs automated unit tests.
Deploy: AWS CodeBuild step which publishes the application, ready to be used.

text: That is all there is to it. Really! This pipeline is now able to listen for any changes we make to the codebase and automatically validate, test and deploy them. Magic! ğŸ¤“
Step 3 â€” CI/CD Pipeline Configuration
There are three types of files within our repo:

texts: Delivery: Files which help us to put our code into an environment
Test: Files which help us to confirm that our code is functioning correctly.
Code/Application: The files which make up the application we are building.

text: In this step, we are focussing on Delivery files. These files will instruct AWS about how to configure our CI/CD pipeline. The file which describes the pipeline, and what the pipeline should do, is delivery/Delivery-Cloudformation.yaml. This file is a type of Infrastructure as Code (IaC).

IaC is the concept of using config files to inform an Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) provider â€” such as AWS â€” how to provision infrastructure on your behalf. Using IaC means that you do not have to provide the infrastructure yourself.
Pipeline Configuration YAML
Before we deploy the pipeline, letâ€™s take a look at the file and see what it is going to create. The file is a Cloudformation file and is in the YAML format.

AWSTemplateFormatVersion: 2010-09-09Description: Infrastructure as Code deployment pipelineParameters:  StackName:    Type: String    Default: delivery-pipeline-tutorial    Description: Name of the Stack  RepositoryName:    Type: String    Default: delivery-pipeline-tutorial    Description: The name of the CodeCommit repository to collect the code from  RepositoryBranch:    Type: String    Default: master    Description: The name of the git branch which should be used for deployments
The first two rows are metadata. The first helps AWS Cloudformation to know how to parse the file. The second helps you to understand what this stack is for following its deployment.

Next, we have Parameters. These parameters are input fields, which allow us to pass in different values, should we wish. They also act as variables which can be reused throughout the rest of the file.

texts: StackName: This is the name which the pipeline will be given once it is created. You can change this to anything you like.
RepositoryName: This is the name of your AWS CodeCommit repository, you must change this to the exact name you chose in Step 1.
RepositoryBranch: If you were to use a branch other than master you would specify it here. However, weâ€™ll use master, so leave it as it is.

text: The third top-level section of the file is Resources. This section contains the description of the assets which we want to deploy. These assets come in pairs: a resource, and itâ€™s IAM role (with one exception). Each of our resources is there to perform a task, for which the resource requires permissions. We define the permissions in the IAM role.
These are the resources:

texts: PipelineBucket: This is the place where our delivery pipeline will be able to store the bits and pieces it needs to do its job. This is the resource which doesnâ€™t need an IAM role.

Pipeline: This is a CodePipeline resource. It is the delivery pipeline itself and defines what stages and actions the pipeline should take. Its role is PipelineRole, and this gives the pipeline permission to put/read objects into the PipelineBucket and also kick-off CodeBuild actions.

Validate: This is a CodeBuild resource. It describes the EC2 server which needs to be provisioned and the actions that server should perform â€” in this case to validate the serverless.yaml file in our repository.
Test: This is the second CodeBuild resource we need. This one is configured to run the python unit tests.
Deploy: The third CodeBuild resource will deploy our application.

text: Step 2 â€” Copy The QuickStart Code
Later in this guide, I will talk you through how all of the code works. For now, all you need to do is copy the basic codebase into your new repo.
From this Github repo, copy out the following files and directories:

texts: delivery/ â€” This contains the resources we need to create and maintain our delivery pipeline.
services/ â€” This contains the application code.
tests/ â€” This contains our automation tests, a key element in CI/CD.

serverless.yaml â€” Weâ€™ll be using the Serverless Framework to help us to deploy our application code. This file tells our delivery pipeline how to deploy and configure our application. It is an IaC file. (Donâ€™t worry you don't need to install Serverless locally).

text: The easiest way is to clone the Github repo. Use:

texts: git clone git@github.com:g-farrow/delivery-pipeline-tutorial.git or
git clone https://github.com/g-farrow/delivery-pipeline-tutorial.git

text: You can now copy the files from the Github repo to your new repo using these commands:

cp -r <Github_repo_location>/delivery <your_repo_location>/cp -r <Github_repo_location>/services <your_repo_location>/cp -r <Github_repo_location>/tests <your_repo_location>/cp <Github_repo_location>/serverless.yaml <your_repo_location>/
translation: cp -r <Github_repo_location> /äº¤ä»˜<your_repo_location> / cp -r <Github_repo_location> /æœåŠ¡<your_repo_location> / cp -r <Github_repo_location> / tests <your_repo_location> / cp <Github_repo_location> / serverlessã€‚

text: Your repo should now look something like this:
<your repo name>  --> delivery/  --> services/  --> tests/  --> serverless.yaml
Now you are ready to push the changes to your AWS CodeComit repo. You can do this easily from the terminal using:
git add .git commit -m "Initial commit containing quickstart files"git push origin
translation: git add .git commit -mâ€œåŒ…å«å¿«é€Ÿå…¥é—¨æ–‡ä»¶çš„åˆå§‹æäº¤â€ git push origin

text: Create a New Repo | AWS CodeCommit
AWS CodeCommit is a Git-based, fully managed service perfect for hobby-projects or Enterprise project alike.
Step 1 â€” Creating Your Code Repository

The foundation of any CI/CD pipeline is the repo. The code repo is where application code is stored and versioned. There are lots of options for version control systems; one of the most popular is Git. In this guide, we will use AWS CodeCommit to store our code. If you need help creating a CodeCommit repo, follow this 3-minute guide:
translation: ä»»ä½•CI / CDç®¡é“çš„åŸºç¡€éƒ½æ˜¯å›è´­åè®®ã€‚ ä»£ç å­˜å‚¨åº“æ˜¯åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºä»£ç çš„å­˜å‚¨å’Œç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚ ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»ç»Ÿæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šé€‰é¡¹ã€‚ æœ€å—æ¬¢è¿çš„ä¹‹ä¸€æ˜¯Gitã€‚ åœ¨æœ¬æŒ‡å—ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä½¿ç”¨AWS CodeCommitå­˜å‚¨æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ä»£ç ã€‚ å¦‚æœæ‚¨åœ¨åˆ›å»ºCodeCommitå­˜å‚¨åº“æ–¹é¢éœ€è¦å¸®åŠ©ï¼Œè¯·æŒ‰ç…§ä»¥ä¸‹3åˆ†é’Ÿçš„æŒ‡å—è¿›è¡Œæ“ä½œï¼š

text: Create a New Repo | AWS CodeCommit
AWS CodeCommit is a Git-based, fully managed service perfect for hobby-projects or Enterprise project alike.
Now that you have a repo, you will need to check it out to your local workstation. The guide above will explain how to do this.
Continuous Delivery in 20 minutes ğŸ
A guide to setting up a CI/CD pipeline from scratch with almost no effort or prior knowledge.
If youâ€™ve never used Continuous Delivery before, it can be an ominous prospect!
All those tools, all that tech, where do I even start!?

That is precisely how I felt when I first encountered Continuous Delivery. Like most things in Software Engineering (and life), the hardest step can be the first. Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve written this guide to get you from rookie to continuous delivery in minutes! Iâ€™ve provided all the code and config that youâ€™ll need.
What is Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Delivery (CD)?
Continuous Integration â€” The practice of having a repository for storing and versioning source code. When a change to the codebase is made, the code is built and validated.
Continuous Delivery â€” The logical extension of CI, once code has been validated and tested, it is then automatically deployed. A manual gateway can be used to allow human control over deployments.
Adopting Continuous Delivery requires a change in mindset towards code changes. Every commit to a repository must be eligible for delivery.
What does this guide cover?

texts: Create a Git repository to store and version our code.
Deploy a Continuous Delivery pipeline to validate our code, run unit tests and deploy our application.
Test how it works by updating our code!

text: Tools and Technology
Iâ€™ll talk you through every step, so you should be able to follow this guide, even if youâ€™re a noob. ğŸ˜€

Weâ€™ll be using AWS to deploy a simple â€œhello worldâ€ serverless app. Everything we do will be in the free tier, so donâ€™t worry about costs. If you donâ€™t already have one, create your account here.
translation: æˆ‘ä»¬å°†ä½¿ç”¨AWSéƒ¨ç½²ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„â€œ hello worldâ€æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚ æˆ‘ä»¬æ‰€åšçš„ä¸€åˆ‡éƒ½æ˜¯å…è´¹çš„ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä¸å¿…æ‹…å¿ƒæˆæœ¬ã€‚ å¦‚æœæ‚¨è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰ï¼Œè¯·åœ¨è¿™é‡Œåˆ›å»ºæ‚¨çš„å¸æˆ·ã€‚

text: Letâ€™s start with our toolkit (again, you donâ€™t need to know anything about these tools, Iâ€™ll explain everything as we go):

texts: AWS CodeCommit â€” This is where we will store our code and manage versions.
AWS CodeBuild â€” This service helps us to validate, test and deploy our app.
AWS CodePipeline â€” This is the thing that brings all the other elements together into our CI/CD pipeline.
Serverless Framework â€” An abstraction around AWS services which helps us get a real application deployed with almost no code.
AWS CLI â€” This helps us to interact with AWS on the command-line. We only need this for two commands.
